title: RedCode Virus
historical_context: This article discusses the creation of a virus inspired by the CoreWars game, reflecting the hacker culture of the late 90s and early 2000s.
short_summary: The article details the creation of the RedCode virus, which simulates a game of CoreWars on a computer. It includes a destructive payload but allows users to avoid damage. The virus is described as a 'joke virus' with humorous elements.
summary:
In this article, Wintermute introduces the RedCode virus, a playful yet destructive piece of malware inspired by the CoreWars programming game. The virus operates as a TSR (Terminate and Stay Resident) COM infector, infecting files upon closing and disinfecting them upon opening. The payload is designed to create a visual game-like experience on the user's screen, where two programs battle against each other, reminiscent of the CoreWars concept. Users can avoid damage by not pressing 'enter' when prompted, showcasing a blend of humor and technical prowess in its design.

The article also delves into the technical aspects of the virus, including its infection mechanism, payload execution, and self-disinfection capabilities. It highlights the author's intention to create a light-hearted virus that, while destructive, offers users a chance to escape its effects. The writing reflects the hacker ethos of the time, combining technical skill with a playful attitude towards malware development, making it a noteworthy read for those interested in the history of computer viruses and hacker culture.
